title: 115_hr5907
content: The Act is known as the National Innovation Modernization by Laboratory Empowerment Act or the NIMBLE Act. It includes definitions for various terms. The NIMBLE Act defines the Department of Energy and National Laboratories, including Ames, Argonne, Brookhaven, Fermi, Idaho, Lawrence Berkeley, National Energy Technology, National Renewable Energy, Oak Ridge, Pacific Northwest, Princeton Plasma Physics, and Savannah River National Laboratories. The NIMBLE Act defines the Department of Energy and National Laboratories, including Savannah River National Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, and any laboratory operated by the National Nuclear Security Administration for civilian energy activities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy. SEC. 3. PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR COMMERCIALIZATION. The Secretary can delegate signature authority to National Laboratory directors for agreements under $1 million, aligned with approved strategic plans or budgets. This applies to various types of agreements determined appropriate by the Secretary and National Laboratory directors. The director of the affected National Laboratory and contractor must adhere to Department policies to ensure no compromise on national interests. They must certify activities to avoid conflicts of interest. The director of a National Laboratory must submit records for review within 30 days of entering an agreement. Higher rates can be charged for services to support research activities. The section does not apply to agreements with majority foreign-owned companies. The NIMBLE Act exempts technology transfer agreements with National Laboratories from requiring approval by the Secretary of Energy, even if they involve majority foreign-owned companies. The NIMBLE Act exempts technology transfer agreements with National Laboratories from requiring approval by the Secretary of Energy for projects costing less than $1 million. SEC. 4. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not affect the primary responsibilities of any National Laboratory to the Department.
